user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of need_100_continue:
```c
static bool
need_100_continue (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  const char *expect;

  if (! MHD_IS_HTTP_VER_1_1_COMPAT (connection->rq.http_ver))
    return false;

  if (0 == connection->rq.remaining_upload_size)
    return false;

  if (MHD_NO ==
      MHD_lookup_connection_value_n (connection,
                                     MHD_HEADER_KIND,
                                     MHD_HTTP_HEADER_EXPECT,
                                     MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ ( \
                                       MHD_HTTP_HEADER_EXPECT),
                                     &expect,
                                     NULL))
    return false;

  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (expect,
                               "100-continue"))
    return true;

  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No suspicious fragments found. The parameter is 'struct MHD_Connection *connection'. The code only dereferences this pointer (connection->...) and passes it by value to functions/macros; there is no assignment to the parameter identifier (no 'connection = ...'), no increment/decrement of the parameter, and no other operation that rebinds or modifies the pointer itself. Assignments to members of the pointed-to object would be permitted by Rule 17.8, but none occur here (only reads of connection->rq.http_ver and connection->rq.remaining_upload_size). Calls such as MHD_lookup_connection_value_n receive the pointer by value; even if those functions modify the object pointed-to, that is allowed by the rule. Therefore no code fragment in this function appears to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
